original: Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: tena vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said:

analyzed: vipassi jina varaḥ vīrosumitta ārāmamhi nibbutaḥ
translated: “The Victorious One, the Hero Vipassī, attained Final Emancipation in the Sumitta Monastery,

original: Sikhī munivaro buddho-dussārāmamhi nibbuto,
analyzed: sikhī muni varaḥ nibbutaḥ
translated: “The excellent sage Sikhi, the Buddha, attained Nibbāna in the Dussāra Grove;

translated: There, too, was built the excellent stūpa, three leagues high.”

original: Tassa aparabhāge vessabhū nāma satthā udapādi. Tadā bodhisatto sudassano nāma rājā🔽hutvā buddhapamukhassa saṅghassa sacīvaramahādānaṃ datvā tassa santike pabbajitvā
analyzed: tassa aparabhāge vessabhū nāma satthā udapādi tadā bodhisatto sudassanaḥ nāma rājā  hutvā buddha pamukhassa saṅghassa sa cīvara mahādānam da tvā tassa santike pabbajitvā

analyzed: mittaḥ ahosi saḥ tena saddhim satthāram upasaṅkamitvā dhamma  katham sutvā pabbajitvā āraddha vīriyaḥ tīṇi piṭakāni uggahetvā vattā vatta sampattiyā

analyzed: mahākassapaḥ jinaḥ nibbutaḥ 🔽tattha iva tassa 🔽ettha ca 🔽dīpaṅkaro ca sumano tathā 🔽anomadassī buddhaḥ ca nāradaḥ padumuttaro

translated: “This insentient earth, which knows neither happiness nor suffering,

analyzed: vāditehi mālehi gaṇdhehi garukarontā mānentā pūjentā nagara majjhena  nīharitvā yattha makuṭabaṇdhanam nāma mallānam cetiyam tattha nikkhipiṃsu

original: pupphena satthatā hoti atha kho kosinārakā mallā bhagavato sarīraṃ cakkavattissa
analyzed: pupphena satthatā hoti atha kho kosi nārakāḥ mallāḥ bhagavato sarīram cakkavattissa

analyzed: sarīram viya ahatena vatthena veṭhesuṃ ahatena vatthena veṭhetvā vihatena kappāsena

analyzed: veṭhetvā āyasāya tela doṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjetvā sabba gaṇdhānaṃ  citakam karitvā bhagavataḥ sarīram citakam āropesum tena khalu pana samayena āyasmā  mahā kassapaḥ pāvāya kusināram paṭipannaḥ hoti mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhiṃ
translated: and then in another iron tub, and then a funeral pyre was built of all kinds of perfumed woods.🔽Then the Mallas of Kusinārā tried to light the funeral pyre,🔽but they were unable to do so.

original: pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi tena kho pana samayena there cittaṃ pasādetvā sagge nibbattā
analyzed: pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi tena kho pana samayena there cittam pasādetvā sagge nibbattā
translated: Then the venerable Maha Kassapa was travelling along the highway from Pava to Kusinara with a large company of some five hundred monks.🔽At that time, after attaining heaven through the faith they had aroused in the Elder, the gods, not seeing the Elder in the assembly, thought: “Where is our venerable friend?”🔽And they asked the Elder: “Venerable sir, why are the Mallas of Kusinara unable to light the Blessed One’s funeral pyre?”🔽“Because I am not there, friend.”🔽“But when will you arrive, venerable sir?”🔽“Tomorrow, friend.”

original: devatā tasmiṃ samāgame theraṃ adisvā kuhinnu kho amhākaṃ kulupaga theroti āvajjento
analyzed: devatā tasmin samāgame theram a disvā kuhin nu khalu amhākam kulupaga theraḥ iti āvajjentaḥ
translated: “Then, venerable sir, please do not tarry.”

original: antarāmaggapaṭipannaṃ disvā amhākaṃ kulupaga there avaṇdite citako mā pajjalitthāti adhiṭṭhihiṃsu.

analyzed: atha kho cattāraḥ malla pāmokkhā sīsam nahātā ahatāni vatthāni nicatthā

analyzed: caṇdana citakam ālimpessāma ati aṭṭha pi solasa pi dvattiṃsā api janāḥ hutvā yamake ukkayo  gahetvā vijantāḥ bhastāni dhamantāḥ na aggim gāhāpetum atha
translated: said: “We will light the funeral pyre.” But although eight, sixteen, and thirty-two men tried to light the pyre with the sticks of incense,🔽they were unable to do so. Then the Mallas of Kusinārā,

analyzed: kho kosinārakā mallā citakassa a pajjalana kāraṇam āyasmantam anuruddham
translated: having asked the Venerable Anuruddha the reason why the pyre would not blaze up,

analyzed: devatānam abhippāyam sutvā mahākassapaḥ kira bho pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim dasabalassa  pāde vaṇdissāmi iti āgacchati tasmin kira anāgate citakaḥ na pajjalati kīdisaḥ bhoso
translated: and having heard that it was the wish of the deities, said: “It is said that the Elder Mahākassapa, together with five hundred monks,

original: parinibbānaṃ nāmāti deci gaṇdhamālādi hatthā paṭipathaṃ gacchiṃsu keci vīthiyo vicittā🔽katvā āgamanamaggaṃ olokayamānā aṭṭhaṃsu. Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena kusinārā
analyzed: parinibbānam nāma ati deci gaṇdha mālā ādi hatthāḥ paṭipatham gacchiṃsu keci vīthiyaḥ vicittāḥ  katvā āgamana maggaṃ olokayamānāḥ aṭṭhaṃsu atha kho āyasmā mahākassapaḥ yena kusinārā
translated: having taken garlands, perfumes, and so on, went out to meet (the body). Some, having decorated the streets,

analyzed: makūṭabaṇdhanam nāma mallānam cetiyam yena bhagavataḥ citako tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā
translated: stood looking at the road by which (the body) would come. Then venerable Mahākassapa went to the Mallas’ shrine called Makuta-bandhana, and after approaching the Fortunate One’s funeral pyre,

original: ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā tikkhattuṃ citakaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā āvajjentova sallakkhesi-imasmiṃ
analyzed: ekaṃsam cīvaram katvā tikkhattum citakam padakkhiṇam katvā āvajjento uva

analyzed: ṭhāne pāda ati tate pāda samīpe ṭhatvā abhiññā pādakam catuttha jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya

analyzed: dasabalassa pādā saddhim kappāsa paṭalehi  suvaṇṇa doṇim vaṇdana citakam ca dvedhā katvā mayham uttamaṅge sirasi patiṭṭhahantu iti

analyzed: adhiṭṭhāsi saha adhiṭṭhāna cittena tāni dussayuga ādini dvedhā katvā valāhaka antarā

analyzed: puṇṇa caṇdaḥ viya pādāḥ nikkhamiṃsu
translated: and his feet came out like the full moon.

analyzed: theraḥ vikasita ratta paduma sadise hatthe pasāretvā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇe satthu pāde yāva  gopphakāḥ bāḷham gahetvā attano sira vare patiṭṭhāpesi mahājanaḥ tam acchariyam disvā

analyzed: eka pahāre na iva mahānādam nadi gaṇdha mālā ādīhi pūjetvā yathārucim eva pana

analyzed: therena ca mahājanena ca tehi ca pañcahi bhikkhu satehi vaṇdita mattetherassa hatthato  muñcitvā alattaka vaṇṇāni bhagavato pāda tālāni dāru ādisu kiñci a cāletvā ava yathāṭṭhāne  patiṭṭhahiṃsu bhagavato pādesu nikkhamantesu vā pavisantesu vā vā
translated: But as soon as the Elder and the great multitude and the five hundred bhikkhus had paid obeisance to him,🔽the Teacher’s feet came out from under the Elder’s hands. original: vā telabiṇdu vā dārukhaṇḍaṃ vā ṭhānā calitaṃ nāma nāhosi. Sabbaṃ yathāṭṭhāne ṭhitameva

analyzed: ahosi uṭṭhahitvā pana atthaṅgate caṇde viya sūriye viya ca tathāgatassa pādesu antarahitesu
translated: But when the Tathāgata’s feet disappeared, the great multitude wept and wailed as they had when the moon had set.

original: mahājano mahākaṇditaṃ kaṇdi. Parinibbutakālato adhikataraṃ kāruññaṃ ahosi atha kho🔽devātānubhāvena panesa citake samantato ekappahāreneva pajjali. Jhāyamānassa bhagavato
analyzed: mahā janaḥ mahā kaṇditam kaṇdi parinibbuta kālataḥ adhikataram kāruññam ahosi atha kho  devātā anubhāvena pana esa citake samantataḥ eka pahārena iva pajjali jhāyamānassa bhagavataḥ

analyzed: sarīrassa chavi camma maṃsa ādīnam na iva chārikā mattam pi antamasaḥ paññāyittha na masi

analyzed: aham na ciram ṭhatvā ṭhatvā parinibbāyāmi mayham sāsanam na tāva sabbattha vitthāritam
translated: “My Dispensation has not yet spread everywhere,🔽so after my final Nibbāna, take my relics and distribute them,

analyzed: kati panassa dhātuyaḥ vippakiṇṇā kati na vippakiṇṇā ati catasso dāṭṭhāḥ dve akkhakā
translated: Now, how many of the relics were distributed, and how many were not distributed? The four eye-teeth, the two collar-bones,

analyzed: imāḥ satta dhātuyaḥ na vippakiṇṇā sesāḥ tattha sabba khuddakā  dhātu sāsapa bīja mattā ahosi mahā dhātu majjhe bhinna taṇḍula mattā atimahatī majjhe

analyzed: suvaṇṇa rajata mayehi aṭṭha dantakehi vikiritvā caṇdana citakam nibbāpesuṃ tattha citake

analyzed: sāla rukkhānam sākha antarehi viṭapa antarehi patta antarehi
translated: The sāla trees which stood in a circle around the pyre, and the creepers and the leaves,

analyzed: nikkhantaḥ udaka dhārāsu pi pamāṇam evam citakam nibbāpetvā pana malla rājāno
translated: After they had extinguished the pyre, the Mallas

analyzed: khacetvā tattha api gaṇdha dāma mālā dāma ratana dāmāni olambetvā maṇi daṇḍehi pañca vaṇṇa dhaje  ussapetvā samantā dhaja patākā pirikkhipitvā sitta sammaṭṭhāsu vīthisu kadaliyaḥ puṇṇa ghaṭe

analyzed: iti samantā yojana ppamāṇam ṭhānam sannāha gacchitam viya katvā ārakkham saṃvidahiṃsu  kasmā pana ete evam akaṃsu iti itas purimesu dvīsu sattāhesu te bhikkhu saṅghassa ṭhāna nisajja ukāsam
translated: Thus they made a space all around a league in extent as if it were filled with an army, and they made a guard.🔽But why did they do this? In the first two weeks they had no opportunity to play well,

translated: by all the world, together with the gods,

original: Namassaneyyāca bhavanti sabbadāti;
analyzed: namassaneyyāca bhavanti sabba dāti
translated: they were worthy of worship and reverence.

original: Dasathūpakathā
analyzed: dasa thūpa kathā
translated: The Ten Monuments

original: 10. Evaṃ patiṭṭhitesu pana thūpesu mahākassapatthero dhātūnaṃ antarāyaṃ disvā ajātasattuṃ🔽upasaṅkamitvā mahārāja ekaṃ dhātunidhānaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatiti āha sādhu bhante nidhānakammaṃ🔽tāva mama hotu, dhātuyo pana kathaṃ āharāpemiti. Na mahārāja dhātu āharaṇaṃ tuyhaṃ
analyzed: evam patiṭṭhitesu pana thūpesu mahākassapa theraḥ dhātūnam antarāyam disvā ajātasattum  upasaṅkamitvā mahā rājaḥ ekam dhātu nidhānam kātum vaṭṭati iti āha sādhu bhante nidhāna kammam  mama hotu na mahā rāja dhātu āharaṇam
translated: When the monuments had been thus established, the Elder Mahā Kassapa saw that the relics were in danger, so he approached Ajātasattu

original: bhāro, amhākaṃ bhāroti. Sādhu bhante tumhe dhātuyo āharatha. Ahaṃ dhātunidhānaṃ karissāmīti.
analyzed: bhāraḥ amhākam bhāraḥ iti sādhu bhante tumhe dhātuyaḥ āharatha aham dhātu nidhānam karissāmi iti
translated: and said, “Great king, it is proper to make a deposit of one portion of the relics.” “Very well, venerable sir, let the work of depositing be done by me; but how shall I have the relics brought?” “Great king, it is not your duty to bring the relics; it is our duty.” “Very well, venerable sir, you bring the relics; I will make the deposit.”

original: Thero tesaṃ tesaṃ rājakulānaṃ paricaraṇamattakameva ṭhapetvā sesedhātuyo āhari.
analyzed: theraḥ tesam tesam rāja kulānam paricaraṇa mattakam eva ṭhapetvā sesa dhātuyaḥ āhari
translated: The elder had the relics brought from all the royal families except that of Rāmagāma, which he left with only the attendance.

original: Rāmagāme pana dhātuyo nāgā gaṇhiṃsu tāsaṃ antarāyo natthi, anāgate laṅkādīpe mahāvihāre
analyzed: rāmagāme pana dhātuyaḥ nāgāḥ gaṇhiṃsu tāsam antarāyaḥ natthi anāgate laṅkādīpe mahāvihāre
translated: But the nāgas seized the relics at Rāmagāma. There was no danger to them, for they would be deposited in the future in the Great Monastery in the island of Laṅkā,

original: mahācetiyamhi nidhiyissa nīti. Tā na āharittha, sesehi sattahi nagarehi āharitvā
analyzed: mahācetiyamhi nidhiyissa nīti tā naḥ āharittha sesehi sattahi nagarehi āharitvā
translated: in the Great Shrine. So he did not bring them. He brought the relics from the other seven cities and deposited them

original: rājagahassa pācīna dakkhina disābhāge ṭhapetvā imasmiṃ ṭhāne yo pāsāṇo atthi, so
analyzed: rājagahassa pācīna dakkhina disā bhāge ṭhapetvā imasmin ṭhāne yo pāsāṇaḥ atthi so
translated: in the south-east quarter of Rājagaha. The stone that is here

original: antaradhāyatu, paṃsu suvisuddhā hotu, udakañca mā uṭṭhahatūti adhiṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: antaradhāyatu paṃsu su visuddhā hotu udakam ca mā uṭṭhahatu iti adhiṭṭhāsi
translated: and the earth disappeared, and the earth became well-cleaned, and the water did not rise up.

original: Rājā taṃ ṭhānaṃ khaṇāpetvā tato uddhaṭa paṃsunā iṭṭhikā kāretvā asīti mahāsāvakānaṃ
analyzed: rājā tam ṭhānam khaṇāpetvā tatas uddhaṭa paṃsunā iṭṭhikā kāretvā asi iti mahā sāvakānam
translated: The King had that place dug up, and he had bricks made from the earth that was dug up, and he built a Thūpa

original: thūpe kāreti idha rājā kiṃ kārehīti pucchantānampi mahāsāvakānaṃcetiyā nīti vadanti
analyzed: thūpe kāreti idha rājā kim vadanti
translated: to the eighty great disciples. When people asked, “What is the King doing here?” he said, “I am building a shrine to the great disciples.”

original: na koci dhātunidhānabhāvaṃ jānāti asītihatthagambhīre pana tasmiṃ padese jāte heṭṭhā🔽lobhasattharaṃ sattharāpetvā tattha thūpārāme cetiya gharappamāṇaṃ tambalohamayaṃ
analyzed: na koci dhātu nidhāna bhāvam jānāti asīti hattha gambhīre pana tasmin padese jāte heṭṭhā  lobha sattharam tattha thūpa ārāme cetiya ghara ppamāṇam tamba loha mayam
translated: No one knew that there was a treasure there. But when that place, which was eighty cubits deep, was dug up,🔽the King had a treasure-house built in the Thūpa-court, the size of the Shrine-house, and he had it made of iron.

original: gehaṃ kārāpetvā aṭṭhaṭṭha hari caṇdanādimaye karaṇḍe ca thūpe ca kārāpesi.
analyzed: geham kārāpetvā aṭṭhaṭṭha hari caṇdana ādi maye karaṇḍe ca thūpe ca kārāpesi

analyzed: atha kho bhagavataḥ dhātuyaḥ haricaṇdana karaṇḍe pakkhipitvā tam haricaṇdanam karaṇḍam
translated: Then he put the relics of the Blessed One in a box of yellow sandalwood, and he put that box of yellow sandalwood

analyzed: aññasmin haricaṇdana karaṇḍe aññasmin ti evam aṭṭha haricaṇdana karaṇḍe ekatas
translated: in another box of yellow sandalwood, and that in another, and so on until he had eight boxes of yellow sandalwood.

original: katvā eteneva upāyena aṭṭha karaṇḍe aṭṭhasu haricaṇdana thūpesu aṭṭha haricaṇdanathūpe🔽aṭṭhasu lohitacaṇdana karaṇḍesu, aṭṭha lohitacaṇdanakaraṇḍe aṭṭhasu lohitacaṇdanathūpesu,

translated: in the eight betel-leaf boxes, in the eight betel-leaf boxes, in the eight betel-leaf boxes,🔽in the

analyzed: maṇi thūpe aṭṭhasu lohitaṅka karaṇḍesu aṭṭha lohitaṅka karaṇḍe aṭṭhasu lohitaṅka thūpesu  aṭṭha lohitaṅka thūpe aṭṭhasu masāragalla thūpesu aṭṭha masāragalla thūpe aṭṭhasu phalika
translated: In the eight red-ochre boxes there were eight red-ochre stupas,🔽in the eight red-ochre stupas there were eight coral stupas,🔽in the eight coral stupas there were eight crystal boxes,

original: karaṇḍesu, aṭṭha phaḷika karaṇḍe aṭṭhasu phaḷikathūpesu pakkhipi sabba uparimaṃ phaḷikacetiyaṃ
analyzed: karaṇḍesu aṭṭha phaḷika karaṇḍe aṭṭhasu phaḷika thūpesu pakkhipi sabba uparimam phaḷika cetiyaṃ
translated: in the eight crystal boxes there was the crystal stupa at the very top.

original: thūpārāma cetiyappamāṇaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: thūpa ārāma cetiya pamāṇam ahosi
translated: It was the size of the Cetiyapabbata stupa in the Thūpārāma.

original: Tassa uparisabbaratanamayaṃ gehaṃ kāresi tassa upari suvaṇṇamayaṃ, tassa upari rajatamayaṃ,
analyzed: tassa upari sabba ratana mayam geham kāresi tassa upari suvaṇṇa mayam tassa upari rajata mayam
translated: Above it he had a house made of all the precious stones, above that one of gold, above that one of silver,

original: tassa upari tambalohamayaṃ gehaṃ kāresi tattha sabbaratanamayaṃ vālukaṃ okiritvā
analyzed: tassa upari tamba loha mayam geham kāresi tattha sabba ratana mayam vālukam okiritvā
translated: above that one of copper, and there he had sand of all the precious stones scattered,

original: jalaja thalaja pupphānaṃ sahassāni vippakiritvā addhacchaṭṭhāni jātakasatāni āsīti
analyzed: jala ja thala ja pupphānam sahassāni vippakiritvā addhacchaṭṭhāni jātaka satāni āsi iti
translated: and thousands of water and land flowers scattered, and there were eighty-four thousand jātakas,

original: mahāthere suddhodana mahārājānaṃ mahāmāyādeviṃ satta sahajāte sabbānetāni suvaṇṇamayāneva
analyzed: mahā there suddhodana mahā rājānam mahāmāyādevim satta sahajāte sabbān etāni suvaṇṇa mayān eva
translated: and the Great Elder had all of these made of gold, the Great Elder Suddhodana, Queen Mahāmāyā, and the seven treasures.

original: kāresi pañcapañcasate suvaṇṇarajatamaye puṇṇaghaṭe ṭhapāpesi pañcasuvaṇṇadhajasate
analyzed: pañca pañca sate suvaṇṇa rajata maye puṇṇa ghaṭe pañca suvaṇṇa dhaja sate
translated: He had five hundred golden and five hundred silver water-pots made, and had them placed there.

original: pañcasate suvaṇṇadīpake ca kārāpetvā sugaṇdhatelassa pūretvā tesu dukūlavaṭṭiyo ṭhapesi.
analyzed: pañcasate suvaṇṇa dīpake ca kārāpetvā sugaṇdha telassa pūretvā tesu dukūla vaṭṭiyaḥ ṭhapesi
translated: He had five hundred golden flags and five hundred golden lamps made, and had them filled with sweet-smelling oil, and had wicks placed in them.

original: Athāyasmā mahākassapo mālā mā milāyantu. Gaṇdhā mā vinassantu, dīpā mā vijjhāyantūti🔽adhiṭṭhahitvā suvaṇṇapaṭṭaakkharāni chiṇdāpesi. Anāgate piyadāso nāma kumāro chattaṃ
analyzed: atha ayasmai mahākassapaḥ mālāḥ mā milāyantu gaṇdhāḥ mā vinassantu dīpāḥ mā vijjhāyantu uti  adhiṭṭhahitvā suvaṇṇa paṭṭa akkharāni chiṇdāpesi anāgate piyadāsaḥ nāma kumāro chattam
translated: Then the venerable Maha Kassapa, thinking, “Let the garlands not fade, let the perfumes not decay, let the lamps not go out,”

original: ussāpetvā asoko nāma dhammarājā bhavissati so imaṃ dhātuyo vitthārikā karissatīti
analyzed: ussāpetvā asokaḥ nāma dhamma rājā bhavissati saḥ imam dhātuyaḥ vitthārikā karissati iti
translated: had the letters on the golden plates cut off. In the future a prince named Piyadassa will raise the umbrella, and will become a righteous king named Asoka. He will spread the relics.

original: rājā sabbapasādhanehi pūjetvā ādito paṭṭhāya dvāraṃ pidahanto nikkhami tambalohadvāraṃ
analyzed: rājā sabba pasādhanehi pūjetvā āditas paṭṭhāya dvāram pidahantaḥ nikkhami tamba loha dvāram
translated: The king worshipped with all the offerings, and closing the door from the beginning, went out. The iron door

original: pidahitvā āviñjana rajjuyaṃ kuñcikamuddikaṃ baṇdhi tattheva mahantaṃ maṇikkhaṇdhaṃ
analyzed: pidahitvā kuñcika muddikam tattha iva mahantam maṇi khaṇdham
translated: having been closed, he fastened the rope-pulley with a padlock. There he placed a great gem-casket,

original: ṭhapesi anāgate daḷiddarājāno imaṃ maṇiṃ gahetvā dhātūnaṃ sakkāraṃ karontūti akkharāni chiṇdāpesī.
analyzed: ṭhapesi anāgate daḷidda rājānaḥ imam maṇim gahetvā dhātūnam sakkāram karontu uti akkharāni
translated: thinking, “In the future poor kings will take this gem and will honour the relics.” He had the letters cut off.

original: Sakko devarājā vissakammaṃ āmantetvā’tāta, ajātasattunā dhātunidhānaṃ kataṃ. Ettha
analyzed: sakkaḥ devarājā vissakammam āmantetvā atāta ajātasattunā dhātu nidhānam katam ettha
translated: Sakka the King of the Gods, having summoned Vissakamma, said: “My dear, Ajātasattu has made a receptacle for the relics.

original: ārakkhaṃ ṭhapehi’ti pahiṇi so āgantvā vāḷasaṅghāṭayantaṃ yojesi. Kaṭṭharūpakāni tasmiṃ🔽dhātugabbhe phaḷikavaṇṇa khagge gahetvā vātasadisena vegena anupariyāyantaṃ yojetvā🔽ekāya eva āṇivā baṇdhitvā samantato giñjaka vasathākārena silāparikkhepaṃ katvā upari
analyzed: ārakkham ṭhapehi ti pahiṇi saḥ āgantvā vāḷa saṅghāṭayantam yojesi kaṭṭharūpakāni tasmin  dhātu gabbhe phaḷika vaṇṇa khagge gahetvā vāta sadisena vegena anupariyāyantam yojetvā  ekāya eva baṇdhitvā samantataḥ giñjaka vasatha ākārena silā parikkhepam katvā upari
translated: You must set a guard there.” He went and set a guard of a troop of demons, who were armed with swords the colour of the flesh, and who were running about with the speed of the wind.🔽Having set them to guard it, he bound it with a single iron chain, and all round he made a stone wall like a rampart,

original: ekāya pidahitvā paṃsuṃ pakkhipitvā bhūmiṃ samaṃ katvā tassupari pāsāṇathūpaṃ patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: ekāya pidahitvā paṃsum pakkhipitvā bhūmim samam katvā tassa upari pāsāṇa thūpam patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: and having covered it above with another iron chain, he filled in the earth and made the ground level, and on top of that he set up a stone stūpa.

original: Dhātunidhāna kathā
analyzed: dhātunidhāna kathā
translated: The story of the receptacle for the relics

original: 11. Evaṃ niṭṭhite dhātunidhāne yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā thero parinibbuto, rājāpi yathākammaṃ
analyzed: evam niṭṭhite dhātunidhāne yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā theraḥ parinibbutaḥ rājā api yathākammam
translated: When the receptacle for the relics had been completed in this way, the Elder, who had lived for his full life-span, attained Nibbāna. The King also went to his destiny according to his kamma.

original: gato, tepi manussā kālakatā, aparabhāge piyadāso kumāro chattaṃ ussāpetvā asoko nāma
analyzed: gataḥ te pi manussā kālakatā aparabhāge piyadāsaḥ kumāro chattam ussāpetvā asokaḥ nāma
translated: Those people also died, and later Prince Piyadāsa, having raised the parasol, became known as King Asoka.

original: dhamma rājā hutvā tā dhātuyo gahetvā jambudīpe caturāsītiyā cetiya sahassesu patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: dhamma rājā hutvā tā dhātuyaḥ gahetvā jambudīpe caturāsītiyā cetiya sahassesu patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: and having become the King of the Dhamma, he took those relics and established them in eighty-four thousand Shrines in the Rose-Apple Island.

original: Kathaṃ biṇdusārassa kira ekasataṃ puttā ahesuṃ te sabbe asoko attanā saddhiṃ ekamātikaṃ
analyzed: katham biṇdusārassa kira eka satam puttāḥ ahesum te sabbe asokaḥ attanā saddhim eka mātikam
translated: It seems that Bindusāra had a hundred sons, and all of them, except for the prince Tissa who was born of the same mother as Asoka,

original: tissa kumāraṃ ṭhapetvā ghātesi. Ghātento cattāri vassāni anabhisitto rajjaṃ kāretvā
analyzed: tissa kumāram ṭhapetvā ghātesi ghātento cattāri vassāni an abhisittaḥ rajjam kāretvā
translated: were killed by Asoka. While killing them he reigned for four years without being anointed,

original: catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena tathāgatassa parinibbānato dvinnaṃ vassasatānaṃ upari
analyzed: catunnam vassānam accayena tathāgatassa parinibbānataḥ dvinnam vassa satānam upari
translated: and after four years had passed, in the eighteenth year after the Realised One’s attainment of Final Emancipation,

original: aṭṭhārasame vasse sakalajambudīpe ekarajjābhisekaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasame vasse sakala jambudīpe eka rajja abhisekam pāpuṇi
translated: he received the anointing for the sole kingship in the whole of the Rose-Apple Island.

original: Abhisekānubhāvena imā rājiddhiyo āgatā mahāpathaviyā heṭṭhā yojanappamāṇe āṇā pavatti,
analyzed: abhiseka anubhāvena imāḥ rājiddhiyaḥ āgatāḥ mahā pathaviyā heṭṭhā yojana ppamāṇe āṇā pavatti
translated: By the power of the anointing these royal wonders came: his command extended a league below the great earth,

original: tathā upari ākāse, anotattadahato aṭṭhahi kājehi soḷasa pānīyaghaṭe divase divase
analyzed: tathā upari ākāse aṭṭhahi kājehi soḷasa pānīya ghaṭe divase divase
translated: and likewise in the sky above, and eight baskets from the Anotatta Lake brought sixteen water-pots of water every day

original: devatā āharanti. Yato sāsane uppannasaddho hutvā aṭṭha ghaṭe bhikkhusaṅghassa adāsi
analyzed: devatāḥ āharanti yatas sāsane uppanna saddhaḥ hutvā aṭṭha ghaṭe bhikkhu saṅghassa adāsi
translated: to the King, and because he had faith in the Dispensation he gave eight pots to the Community of monks🔽and four to the nuns.

original: dve ghaṭe saṭṭhimattānaṃ tipiṭaka bhikkhunaṃ dveghaṭe aggamahesiyā asaṇdhimittāya
analyzed: dve ghaṭe bhikkhunam dve ghaṭe aggamahesiyā a saṇdhi mittāya
translated: two for the sixty Tipiṭaka Bhikkhus, two for the chief queen, Asandhimittā,

original: cattāro ghaṭe attanā paribhuñji. Devatā eva himavante nāgalatā dantakaṭṭha nāma atthi
analyzed: cattāraḥ ghaṭe attanā devatā eva himavante nāgalatā dantakaṭṭha nāma atthi

analyzed: rājā tuṭṭhaḥ suvaṇṇa bhiṃkāram gahetvā therassa hatthe udakam pātetvā mahā meghavan uyyānam

analyzed: puna divase aggikkhaṇdhopama suttantam kathesi etena iva upāyena satta divasāni kathesi  aḍḍha pāṇa sahassānam dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi sattame divase pana thero antopure

We have no opportunity to salute him, to attend on him, to make reverential salutations to him, to do acts of kindness to him.

translated: Sumana replied, “Do not worry, great king. Have the streets cleaned and decorated with banners, flags, and filled jars,🔽and with your retinue observe the Uposatha precepts. Have all the musicians play,

translated: and have the royal elephant decorated with all ornaments. Above him hold a white parasol. In the evening

translated: to me.” “Very well, reverend Sir,” and Sakka, the King of the Gods, after uncovering a gem-thūpa that was a league in size,

translated: having placed the relics given by King Asokadhamma on the Cetiya Mountain, took the right collar-bone

analyzed: hutvā pucchi dhātum bhante kim karomi iti hatthi kumbhiyā iva tāva mahā rāja ṭhapehi iti  rājā dhātu vaṅgoṭakam hatthi kumbhe ṭhapesi pamuditaḥ nāgaḥ kuñcanādam nadi mahā megho

original: pāpuṇiṃsu. Bhikkhunīnaṃ catuddasa sahassānīti.
analyzed: pāpuṇiṃsu bhikkhunīnam catuddasa sahassāni iti

original: Thūpāramha kathā
analyzed: thūpāramha kathā
translated: The Story of the Great Shrine

original: 21. Tato rājā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ vaṇditvā yāca mahācetiyaṃ niṭṭhātināva me bhikkhusaṅgho

original: bhikkhaṃ gaṇhātūti āha. Bhikkhū nādhivāsesu, anupubbena yācanto upallabhikkhūnaṃ🔽sattāhaṃ adhivāsanaṃ labhitvā thūpaṭṭhānassa samantato aṭṭhārasasu ṭhānesu maṇḍape🔽kārayitvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ nisīdāpetvā sattāhaṃ mahādānaṃ datvā sabbesaṃyeva tela-madhu-pāṇitādi
analyzed: bhikkham gaṇhātu uti āha bhikkhū na adhivāsesu anupubbena yācantaḥ upalla bhikkhūnam  satta aham adhivāsanam labhitvā thūpa ṭṭhānassa samantataḥ aṭṭhārasasu ṭhānesu maṇḍape  kārayitvā bhikkhu saṅgham nisīdāpetvā sattāham mahā dānam da tvā sabbesam yeva tela madhu pāṇi tādi
translated: “May the Community of Bhikkhus accept my alms,” he said. The Bhikkhus did not consent, but after gradually asking they obtained the Community of Bhikkhus’ consent for seven days.

original: bhesajjaṃ datvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ vissajjesi tato nagare bheriṃcārāpetvā sabbe iṭṭhaka🔽vaḍḍhaki santipātesi. Te pañcasatamattā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: bhesajjam datvā bhikkhu saṅgham vissajjesi tatas nagare bheriṃcārāpetvā sabbe  vaḍḍhaki te pañca sata mattāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: After having pavilions made in eighteen places all round the site of the Shrine, and after seating the Community of Bhikkhus, he gave a great gift for seven days, and after giving medicine of oil, honey, ghee, etc., to all, he dismissed the Community of Bhikkhus. Then after having a proclamation made in the city, he assembled all the brick-makers who were about five hundred in number.

original: Tesu eko ahaṃ rañño cittaṃ ārādhetvā mahācetiyaṃ kātuṃ sakkomīti rājānaṃ passi rājā
analyzed: tesu ekaḥ aham rañño cittam ārādhetvā mahā cetiyam kātum sakkomi iti rājānam passi rājā
translated: Among them one said: “I can please the King’s mind and build the Great Shrine.” He went to the King and said: “Great King, I will build the Great Shrine.” The King said: “Very well, build it.”

original: kathaṃ karosīti pucchi. Ahaṃ deva pesikānaṃ sataṃ gahetvā ekāhaṃ ekaṃ paṃsusakaṭaṃ
analyzed: katham karosi iti pucchi aham deva pesikānam satam gahetvā ekāham ekam paṃsu sakaṭam
translated: “How do you do it?”🔽“I get a hundred weavers, and in one day I get one cartload of cloth.

original: khepetvā kammaṃ karomīti āha. Rājā evaṃ sati paṃsurāsikaṃ bhavissati. Tiṇarukkhādīni🔽uppajjissanti addhānaṃ nappavattatīti taṃ paṭibāhi.
analyzed: khepetvā kammam karomi iti āha rājā evam sati paṃsurāsikam bhavissati tiṇa rukkha ādīni  uppajjissanti addhānam na pavattati iti tam paṭibāhi
translated: “How do you do it?” “I take a hundred men, and in one day I make them throw out one cart-load of sand.” The king said, “In that case there will be a heap of sand. Grass, trees, and so on will grow up in it, and the road will not be opened.” And he forbade him to do it.

original: Añño ahaṃ purisasataṃ gahetvā ekāhaṃ ekaṃ paṃsugumbaṃ khepetvā kammaṃ karomīti āha.

analyzed: paṃsūnam pañcammaṇāni khepetvā kammam karomi iti āha
translated: Another said, “I make them throw out five measures of sand.”

analyzed: mahantam udaka bubbulam uṭhṭhāsi devaḥ īdisam karomi iti āha  rājā sādhu uti sampaṭicchitvā tassa sahassa gghanakam sāṭaka yugalam sahassa gghanakam yeva
translated: “I will make it like this,” said the god.

analyzed: uppādetvā puppha pūjam olokentaḥ aṭṭhāsi  balatthaḥ tasmin kāle tam theram upasaṅkamitvā vaṇditvā evam āha bhante tumhākam cetiya kamme

analyzed: bodhimaṇḍam āruyha nisinna ṭhānam ca sabbam vitthārena kāresi  tatas mahiṇda thera pamukhe satta saha āgate ca kārāpesi catusu disāsu khaggahatthe

original: gahetvā ṭhitadevatāyo tato padumāni gahetvā ṭhita devatāyo tato chattāni gahetvā🔽ṭhitadevatāyo tato vicittavesadhare malladevaputte tato dussapoṭhana devatāyo tato

translated: Herein, the amount of the various kinds of worship materials mentioned is infinite and immeasurable.🔽For example, there was a bhikkhu named Cittagutta who lived at Ambapāṭhīna. He was preaching the Dhamma to twelve thousand bhikkhus who had assembled in the lower palace.

translated: Beginning the Rathavinīta Sutta, he was extolling the great value of the Dhamma. But thinking that some would not believe him, he desisted and did not finish.🔽At that moment, a bhikkhu named Mahā Tissa, a forest-dweller and an arahat, who was sitting not far away, said to him, “Friend, there are some who have not heard your discourse.

original: bhuñjati. Ekadivasaṃ vinicchaye nisīditva dubbīnicchitaṃ aṭṭaṃ vinicchinanto atisāyaṃ🔽vuṭṭhito thūpavaṇdanaṃ vissaritvā bhojane upanīte hatthaṃ otāretvā manusse pucchiajja

analyzed: dhātu gabbham dassetum ekam theram āṇāpesum rājānam ānetvā dhātu gabbhā olokāpetvā  pesehi iti saḥ raññaḥ hatthe gahetvā dhātu gabbham pavesetvā yathārucim vaṇdāpetvā sabbam

translated: displayed. He assembled the people of the city and said, “The golden images I saw in the relic chamber

analyzed: adhikāram kathetvā uṭṭhāsi tattha ekaḥ bhikkhu rājānam pucchi mahā rāja
translated: When he was unable to finish, he rose. There a monk asked the king, “Great king,

analyzed: tvam pāta rāsa bhattam bhūtvā āgataḥ asi tiyāma rattim vaṇṇentaḥ dhātu gabbhe pūjā vidhimpi

translated: “What can I say, venerable sir? What I have said is not even a tenth of what I have to say.”

analyzed: dhātu gabbhe nirantaram katvā na sukaram pagā iva yathāraham saṃvidhātu tiṭṭhatu  tāva dhātu gabbhaḥ yāva mahā cetiye na
translated: Thus, it is not possible to fill up the relic chamber, which is one hundred and eighty cubits long and wide, with the worshipful objects, which are to be worshipped, without leaving any space in between. How much less possible is it to arrange them in the proper order.

original: sakkā. Tasmā taṃ sabbaṃ pūjanīyabhaṇḍaṃ tattha kathaṃ gaṇhīti yadettha vattabbaṃ porāṇehi vuttameva.
analyzed: sakkā tasmā tam sabbam pūjanīya bhaṇḍam tattha katham gaṇhi iti yat ettha vattabbam porāṇehi vuttam eva
translated: Let alone the relic chamber, it is not possible to fill up the relic chamber with sand up to the boundary of the great cetiya without leaving any space in between. Therefore, how can all those worshipful objects be placed there? What is to be said here has already been said by the ancients.

original: Nigro dhapiṭṭhi tepiṭaka mahāsīvatthero kira rājagehe nisiditvā rañño dasabala sīhanādasutataṃ
analyzed: nigraḥ dhapiṭṭhi tepiṭaka mahāsīva theraḥ kira rājagehe nisiditvā raññaḥ dasabala
