original: Saha dhātu patiṭṭhānā akampittha mahāmahī, pāṭihīrāni nekāni pavattiṃsu anekadhā.”
analyzed: saha dhātu patiṭṭhānā akampittha mahāmahī pāṭihīrāni nekāni pavattiṃsu anekadhā
translated: And as the relics were deposited, the great earth trembled, and many miracles occurred in various ways.”

original: Tadahi udakapariyantaṃ katvā ayaṃ mahāpathavī saṅkampi sampakampi sampavedhi, mahāsamuddo
analyzed: tat ahi udaka pariyantam katvā ayam mahā pathavī saṅkampi sampakampi sampavedhi mahā samuddaḥ
translated: Then the great earth, as far as the ocean, trembled, shook, and quaked. The great ocean

original: saṅkhūbhi, ākāse vijjullatā nicchariṃsu. Khaṇikavassaṃ vassi, cha devalokā ekakolāhala
analyzed: ākāse deva lokāḥ
translated: was agitated, and flashes of lightning appeared in the sky. A momentary rain fell, and the six divine worlds were filled with a great uproar.

original: mahosi rājā etaṃ acchariyaṃ disvā pasanno attano kañcana mālika setacchattena dhātuyo
analyzed: mahā usi rājā etam acchariyam disvā pasannaḥ attanaḥ kañcana mālika seta chattena dhātuyaḥ
translated: Seeing this miracle, the king was pleased. He worshipped the relics with his golden garland and white parasol,

original: pūjetvā tambapaṇṇidipe rajjaṃ sattāhaṃ datvā tiṃsa satasahassagghanakaṃ alaṅkāra
analyzed: pūjetvā tamba paṇṇi dipe rajjam sattāham da tvā alaṅkāra
translated: and after giving the kingdom of Tambapaṇṇi for seven days, he removed the ornaments worth three hundred thousand and worshipped them.

original: bhaṇḍaṃ omuñcitvā pūjesi. Tathā sabbāpi nāṭakitthiyo amaccā sesa mahājano devā ca
analyzed: bhaṇḍam omuñcitvā pūjesi tathā sabbā api nāṭakitthiyaḥ amaccā sesa mahājanaḥ devā ca
translated: In the same way, all the dancing girls, ministers, the rest of the great multitude, and the gods

original: sabbābharaṇāni pūjesuṃ tasmā-
analyzed: sabba ābharaṇāni pūjesum tasmai
translated: worshipped all the ornaments. Therefore,

original: Tiṭṭhantaṃ sugataṃ tilokamahitaṃ yo pūjaye sādaraṃ,
analyzed: tiṭṭhantam sugatam ti loka mahitam pūjaye sādaram
translated: He who reverently worships the Sugata, the Honored One of the Three Worlds,

original: Yo vā sāsapa bījamattampi taṃ dhātuṃ naro pūjaye;
analyzed: yaḥ vā tam dhātum naraḥ pūjaye
translated: Or a person who worships even a mustard seed-sized relic of him;

original: Tesaṃ puññaphalaṃ samānamīti taṃ cittappasāde same,
analyzed: tesam puñña phalam tam citta ppasāde same
translated: The fruit of their merit is the same, thus it is said in the equality of faith in the mind,

original: Ñatvā taṃ parinibbutepi sugate dhātuṃ budho pūjaye’ti;
analyzed: ñatvā tam parinibbute api sugate dhātum budhaḥ pūjaya iti
translated: “Having known that the Sugata has attained Nibbāna, let the wise one worship the relics.”

original: Tato rājā cīvaravatthāni ceva guḷa-sappi ādi bhesajjāni ca saṅghassa datvā sabbarattiṃ
analyzed: tatas rājā cīvara vatthāni ca iva guḷa sappi ādi bhesajjāni ca saṅghassa da tvā sabbarattim
translated: Then the king gave to the Community the cloth and the medicine of treacle, ghee, etc., and he made them recite the texts all night long.

original: gaṇasajjhāyaṃ kāresi puna divase nagare bheriṃ carāpesi mahājano imaṃ sattāhaṃ gaṇdhamālādīni🔽ādiya gantvā dhātuyo vaṇdatūti iṇdaguttattheropi sakala tambapaṇṇi dīpe manussā dhātuyo
analyzed: gaṇa sajjhāyam kāresi puna divase nagare bherim mahā janaḥ imam sattāham gaṇdha mālā ādīni  gantvā dhātuyaḥ vaṇdatu iti manussāḥ dhātuyaḥ
translated: The next day he had the drum beaten in the city, and the great multitude, taking perfumes, garlands, etc., went to worship the relics for seven days.

original: vaṇditukāmā, taṃ khaṇaṃyeva āgantvā vaṇditvā yathāṭṭhānaṃ gacchantūti adhiṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: vaṇditu kāmā tam khaṇaṃyā iva āgantvā vaṇditvā yathāṭṭhānam gacchantu iti adhiṭṭhāsi
translated: The Elder Iṇḍagutta also made a resolve that all the people in the whole island of Tambapaṇṇi who wished to worship the relics should come at once, worship them, and then go back to their homes.

original: Te tatheva dhātuyo vaṇditvā gamiṃsu rājā sattāhaṃ saṅghassa mahādānaṃ pavattetvā
analyzed: te tathā iva dhātuyaḥ vaṇditvā gamiṃsu rājā sattāham saṅghassa mahādānam pavattetvā
translated: They did so, and after worshipping the relics they went away. The king gave great gifts to the Community for seven days,

original: sattāhassa accayena dhātugabbhe mayā kattabbakiccaṃ niṭṭhāpitaṃ, dhātugabbhaṃ pidahatha
analyzed: satta ahassa accayena dhātu gabbhe mayā kattabba kiccam niṭṭhāpitam dhātu gabbham pidahatha
translated: and at the end of the seven days he announced to the Community, “Venerable sirs, I have finished what I had to do in the relic chamber. Close the relic chamber, sirs.”

original: bhanteti saṅghassa ārocesi. Saṅgho uttarasumana sāmaṇere āmantetvā tumhehi pubbe
analyzed: bhante ti saṅghassa ārocesi saṅghaḥ uttarasumana sāmaṇere āmantetvā tumhehi pubbe
translated: The Community summoned the novice Sumana and said to him,

original: āhaṭa medavaṇṇa pāsāṇena dhātu gabbhaṃ pidahathāti āha. Te sādhūti sampaṭicchitvā
analyzed: pāsāṇena dhātu gabbham pidahatha ati āha te sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā
translated: “Cover the relic chamber with a stone the colour of fresh butter.” They agreed, saying, “Very well,”

original: dhātugabbhaṃ pidahiṃsu.
analyzed: dhātu gabbham pidahiṃsu
translated: and they covered the relic chamber with a stone.

original: Tato khīṇāsavā dhātugabbhe gaṇdhā mā susantu mālā mā milāyantu. Dīpā mā nibbāyantu
analyzed: tatas khīṇa āsavāḥ dhātu gabbhe gaṇdhāḥ mā susantu mālāḥ mā milāyantu dīpāḥ mā nibbāyantu
translated: Then the arahats made a resolve that the perfumes in the relic chamber should not decay, that the garlands should not fade, that the lamps should not go out,

original: ratanāni mā vivaṇṇāni hontu pūjanīyabhaṇḍāni mā nassantu. Medavaṇṇa pāsāṇā saṇdhiyantu,
analyzed: ratanāni mā vivaṇṇāni hontu pūjanīya bhaṇḍāni mā nassantu meda vaṇṇa pāsāṇā saṇdhiyantu
translated: that the precious objects should not lose their brilliance, that the objects of worship should not be lost, that the stone the colour of fresh butter should be firmly fixed,

original: paccatthikānaṃ okāso mā hotūti adhiṭṭhahiṃsu.
analyzed: paccatthikānam okāsaḥ mā hotu uti adhiṭṭhahiṃsu
translated: and that there should be no opportunity for enemies.

original: Evaṃ rājā dhātu nidhāpetvā puna nagare bheriṃ carāpesi mahā cetiye dhātuṃ nidhāpetvā🔽dhātuṃ āharitvā nidhānaṃ karontūti. Mahājano attano attano balānurūpena suvaṇṇa rajatādi🔽karaṇḍe kārāpetvā tattha dhātuyo patiṭṭhāpetvā dhātunidhānassupari medavaṇṇa pāsāṇa
analyzed: evam rājā dhātu nidhāpetvā punar nagare bherim mahā cetiye dhātum nidhāpetvā  dhātum āharitvā nidhānam karontu iti mahā janaḥ attanaḥ attanaḥ bala anurūpena rajata ādi  karaṇḍe kārāpetvā tattha dhātuyaḥ patiṭṭhāpetvā meda vaṇṇa pāsāṇa
translated: After the king had thus deposited the relics, he had the drum beaten in the city again, saying, “Having deposited the relics in the Great Relic Shrine,🔽bring the relics and make a deposit.” The people, according to their means, had made for the relics receptacles of gold, silver,

original: piṭṭhiyaṃ nidahiṃsu. Sabbehi sannihita dhātuyo sahassamattā ahesunti.
analyzed: piṭṭhiyam nidahiṃsu sabbehi sannihita dhātuyaḥ sahassa mattāḥ ahesunti
translated: and so on, and they placed the relics in these receptacles and deposited them on the stone slab the colour of fresh butter over the relic deposit. It is said that the total number of relics deposited by all was about a thousand.

original: Iti sādhujana manopasādanatthāya kate thūpavaṃse dhātunidhāna kathā niṭṭhitā.🔽24. Tato rājā taṃ sabbaṃ pidahetvā cetiyaṃ karonto udarena saddhiṃ caturassa koṭṭhakaṃ
analyzed: iti sādhu jana mana upasādana tthāya kate thūpa vaṃse dhātunidhāna kathā niṭṭhitā  tatas rājā tam sabbam pidahetvā cetiyam karontaḥ udarena saddhim caturassa koṭṭhakam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the enshrining of the relics in the Thūpavamsa, composed for the purpose of gladdening the hearts of the good people.🔽. Then the king, having closed up all the relics, and building the Cetiya,

original: niṭṭhāpesi atha chattakamme sudhākamme ca aniṭṭhiteyeva māraṇantika rogena gilāno🔽hutvā dīghavāpito kaniṭṭhabhātaraṃ pakkosāpetvā cetiye aniṭṭhitaṃ chattakammaṃ sudhākammañca
analyzed: niṭṭhāpesi atha chatta kamme sudhā kamme ca māraṇa antika rogena gilānaḥ  hutvā dīgha vāpitaḥ kaniṭṭha bhātaram pakkosāpetvā cetiye a niṭṭhitam chatta kammam sudhā kammañca
translated: finished the four-cornered base together with the dome. Then, before the work on the umbrella and the plastering was completed, he was afflicted with a disease that was near to death.

original: sīghaṃ niṭṭhāpetvā maṃ tosehi tātāti āha. So rañño dubbalabhāvaṃ ñatvā antare aniṭṭhitakammaṃ🔽kātuṃ na sakkāti suddhavatthehi kañcukaṃ kāretvā cetiye paṭimuñcāpetvā cittakārehi🔽kañcuka matthake vedikā ca puṇṇaghaṭa pañcaṅguli pantiyo ca kārāpesi.
analyzed: sīgham niṭṭhāpetvā mam tosehi tāta ati āha saḥ raññaḥ dubbala bhāvam ñatvā antare aniṭṭhita kammaṃ  kātum na sakkāti suddha vatthehi kañcukam kāretvā cetiye paṭimuñcāpetvā citta kārehi  kañcuka matthake vedikā ca puṇṇaghaṭa pañcaṅguli pantiyo ca kārāpesi
translated: Having become very weak, he sent for his younger brother Dīghavāpi Tissa, and said to him: “Dear brother, finish quickly the work on the umbrella and the plastering of the Cetiya, and gladden me.” He, knowing the weakness of the king, thought that it was not possible to finish the work that was not yet completed,🔽and therefore he had a covering made of pure cloth, and had the Cetiya wrapped up in it. He had the artists make a railing on the top of the covering, and also full jars and five-fingered palm-leaves.

original: Naḷakārehi veḷumaya chattaṃ kāretvā kharapattamaye caṇdasūriyamaṇḍale muddhani vedikā
analyzed: naḷa kārehi chattam kāretvā khara patta maye caṇda sūriya maṇḍale muddhani vedikā
translated: He had the umbrella made of reeds, and the sun and moon discs of copper, and a railing on the top of the umbrella.

original: kāretvā lākhākukuṭṭhakehi taṃ vicittaṃ katvā thūpakammaṃ niṭṭhitanti rañño arocesi
analyzed: kāretvā lākhā kukuṭṭhakehi tam vicittam katvā thūpa kammam niṭṭhitanti raññaḥ arocesi
translated: and having it painted with lac and gold, he announced to the king that the work on the Thūpa was finished.

original: rājā tena hi maṃ mahācetiyaṃ dassehīti vatvā sivikāya nipajjitvā cetiyā padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: rājā tena hi mama mahā cetiyam dassehi iti vatvā sivikāya nipajjitvā cetiyā padakkhiṇam
translated: The king said: “Well then, show me the Great Thūpa.” And lying down on a litter, he went round the Thūpa,

original: katvā dakkhiṇadvāre bhūmisayanaṃ paññāpetvā tattha nipanno dakkhiṇena passena sayitvā
analyzed: katvā dakkhiṇa dvāre bhūmi sayanam paññāpetvā tattha nipannaḥ dakkhiṇena passena sayitvā
translated: and having had a bed prepared on the ground at the southern gate, he lay down on his right side.

original: mahāthūpaṃ vāmapassena sayitvā lohapāsādaṃ olokento pasanna citto ahosi. Tadā rañño
analyzed: mahā thūpam vāma passena sayitvā loha pāsādam olokento pasanna cittaḥ ahosi tadā rañño
translated: And lying there, he looked at the Great Thūpa with his right side, and looking at the Lohapāsāda with his left side, he was filled with joy. At that time,

original: sāsanassa bahūpakārabhāvaṃ sallakkhetvā gilāna pucchanatthāya tato tato āgatā bhikkhu
analyzed: sāsanassa bahu upakāra bhāvam sallakkhetvā gilāna pucchana tthāya tatas tatas āgatā bhikkhu
translated: seeing the great benefit of the king’s command, monks who had come from various places to inquire after the king’s health,

original: channavuti koṭiyo rājānaṃ parivāretvā aṭṭhaṃsu. Tato saṅgho vagga vaggā hutvā gaṇasajjhāyaṃ akāsi.🔽Rājā tasmiṃ samāgame theraputtābhayattheraṃ adisvā evaṃ cintesi. So mayi damiḷehi
analyzed: channavuti koṭiyaḥ rājānam parivāretvā aṭṭhaṃsu tatas saṅghaḥ vagga vaggā hutvā gaṇa sajjhāyam akāsi  rājā tasmin samāgame thera putta abhaya theram a disvā evam cintesi saḥ mayi damiḷehi
translated: and who numbered ninety-six koṭis, surrounded the king and stood there. Then the Saṅgha, divided into groups, held a discussion.🔽The king, not seeing the Thera Appamaññāputta in that assembly, thought thus: “He did not fail me in the twenty-eight great battles which I fought with the Damiḷas,

original: saddhiṃ aṭṭhavīsati mahāyuddhe kayiramāse apaccosakakitvā idāni maraṇayuddhe vattamāṇe
analyzed: saddhim aṭṭhavīsati mahā yuddhe kayira māse idāni maraṇa yuddhe vattamāṇe
translated: and now that the battle of death is being fought, he has failed me.”

original: mayhaṃ parājayaṃ disvā maññe nāgacchatīti. Tadā thero kariṇda nadī sīse pajjalita
analyzed: mayham parājayam disvā maññe na āgacchati iti tadā thero
translated: “I think he is coming to see my defeat.” At that time the Elder was living on a mountain at the head of the Kalinga River,🔽which was burning with fire.

original: pabbate vasanto rañño parivitakkaṃ ñatvā pañcasata khīṇāsava parivusetā ākāsenāgantvā
analyzed: pabbate vasantaḥ rañño parivitakkam ñatvā ākāsena āgantvā
translated: Knowing the king’s thoughts, he came through the air with five hundred Arahants as his retinue

original: rañño purato pāturahosi.🔽Rājā theraṃ disvā attano purato nisīdāpetvā evamāha bhante tumhehi saddhiṃ dasamahā
analyzed: raññaḥ puratas pātuḥ ahosi  rājā theram disvā evam āha bhante tumhehi saddhim
translated: and appeared before the king.🔽Seeing the Elder, the king had him sit down in front of him and said, “Venerable sir, I fought with the Dāmis with you and the ten great warriors.

original: yodhe gahetvā damiḷehi saddhi yujdhiṃ. Idāni ekakova maccūnā saddhiṃ yujjhituṃ ārabhiṃ.
analyzed: yodhe gahetvā damiḷehi saddhi yujdhim idāni ekakā uva maccūnā saddhim yujjhitum ārabhim
translated: Now I have begun to fight with Death alone.

original: Maccu sattumpana parājetuṃ na sakkomīti. Tato-
analyzed: maccu sattumpana parājetum na sakkomi iti tatas
translated: I cannot conquer the enemy Death.” Then the Elder

original: Theraputtābhayatthero mā bhāyi manujādhipa,
analyzed: thera putta abhaya theraḥ mā bhāyi manuja adhipa
translated: said, “Do not be afraid, O lord of men.

original: Kilesa sattuṃ ajinitvā ajeyyo maccūsattuko;
analyzed: sattum a jinitvā ajeyyaḥ maccūsattukaḥ
translated: Having conquered the enemy defilements, Death is no more to be feared.”

original: Iti vatvā evaṃ anusāsi. Mahārāja sabboyeva loka sannivāse jātiyā anugato, jarāya anusaṭo, vyādhinā abhibhūto, maraṇena abbhāhato. Tetāha-
analyzed: iti vatvā evam mahā rāja sabboyā iva loka sannivāse jātiyā anugataḥ jarāya vyādhinā abhibhūtaḥ maraṇena
translated: Having said this, he instructed the king thus: “Great king, all the world’s inhabitants are subject to birth, subject to old age, subject to disease, subject to death.”

original: “Yathāpi selā vipulā-nahaṃ āhacca pabbatā,
analyzed: yathā api selā vipula ānaham āhat ca pabbatā
translated: “Just as though huge mountains of solid rock

original: Samantā anupariyeyyuṃ-nippothentā catuddisaṃ;
analyzed: samantāḥ catuddisam
translated: would come from all sides and crush them on every side,

original: Evaṃ jarā ca maccu ca-adhivattanti pāṇino,
analyzed: evam jarā ca maccu ca adhivattanti pāṇinaḥ
translated: so old age and death come upon living beings,

original: Khattiyo brāhmaṇe vesse sudde caṇḍāla pukkuse,
analyzed: khattiyaḥ brāhmaṇe vesse sudde caṇḍāla pukkuse
translated: whether they be nobles, brahmans, merchants, workers, outcastes, or scavengers,

original: Na kiñci parivajjeti-sabbamevābhimaddati;
analyzed: na kiñci parivajja iti sabbam eva abhimaddati
translated: and crush them all without exception.

original: Na tattha hatthinaṃ bhūmi-na rathānaṃ na pattiyā,
analyzed: na tattha hatthinam rathānam na pattiyā
translated: There is no place for elephants, chariots, or infantry,

original: Na cāpi mantayuddhena-sakkā jetuṃ dhanena vā”ti;
analyzed: na ca api manta yuddhena sakkā jetum dhanena vāti
translated: nor can it be overcome by spells or by wealth.”

original: Tasmā idaṃ maraṇaṃ nāma mahāyasānaṃ mahāsammatādīnaṃ mahā puññānaṃ jotiyādīnaṃ mahāthāmānaṃ
analyzed: tasmai idam maraṇam nāma mahā yasānam mahā sammata ādīnam mahā puññānam jotiya ādīnam mahā thāmānam
translated: Therefore, this death overpowers even those of great power, such as Mahāsammata and others, those of great merit, such as Jotipāla and others, those of great strength,

original: baladevādīnaṃ iddhimantānaṃ mahāmoggallānādīnaṃ paññāvantānaṃ sāriputtādīnaṃ sayambhūñāṇena
analyzed: baladeva ādīnam iddhimantānam mahāmoggallāna ādīnam paññāvantānam sāriputta ādīnam sayambhu ñāṇena
translated: such as Baladatta and others, those with psychic powers, such as Mahāmoggallāna and others, those with wisdom, such as Sāriputta and others, those who have attained the truth through their own wisdom,

original: adhigata saccānaṃ, paccekabuddhānaṃ sabbaguṇasamannāgatānaṃ sammāsambuddhānampi upari
analyzed: adhigata saccānam paccekabuddhānam sabba guṇa samannāgatānam sammāsambuddhānam pi upari
translated: such as the Paccekabuddhas, and even those who are endowed with all good qualities, the Fully Enlightened Buddhas.

original: nirāsaṅkameva patati kimaṅgapanaññesu sattesu.
analyzed: nirāsaṅkam eva patati kimaṅga panaññesu sattesu
translated: It falls upon them without hesitation, so what to speak of other beings?

original: Tasmā-
analyzed: tasmā
translated: Therefore,

original: Mahāyasā rājavarā gatā te sabbe mahāsammata ādayopi,
analyzed: mahā yasāḥ rāja varāḥ gatā te sabbe mahāsammata ādayaḥ api
translated: those great kings of great power, all of them, starting with Mahāsammata,

original: Aniccabhāvaṃ baladeva ādi mahābalā ceva tathā gamiṃsu;
analyzed: anicca bhāvam baladevaḥ ādi mahābalā ca iva tathā gamiṃsu
translated: The mighty Baladeva and others, mighty as they were, went the same way.

original: Ye puññavantāni gatā pasiddhiṃ mahaddhanaṃ jotiyameṇḍakādī,
analyzed: ye puññavantāni gatā pasiddhim mahat dhanam
translated: Those who were rich in merit, such as Jotiyameṇḍaka, attained great wealth,

original: Upāvisiṃ vaccumukhaṃ sabhogā sabbepi te rāhumukhaṃ sasīva;
analyzed: upāvisim vaccu mukham sabhogā sabbe api te rāhu mukham sasi iva
translated: But all of them entered the mouth of death, like the moon and stars entering the mouth of Rāhu.

original: Yo iddhimantesu tathāgatassa puttesuseṭṭho iti vissutopi,
analyzed: yaḥ iddhimantesu tathāgatassa puttesu seṭṭhaḥ iti vissutaḥ api
translated: Even the most famous of the Buddha’s disciples, who possessed great psychic powers,

original: Thero mahārājasaheva iddhibalena so maccumukhaṃ paviṭṭho;
analyzed: theraḥ mahā rāja sahevaḥ iddhi balena saḥ maccu mukham paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: The Elder Mahārāja, with his psychic power equal to that of the great kings, entered the mouth of death.

original: Sabbesu sattesu jinaṃ ṭhapetvā nevatthi paññāya samopi yena,
analyzed: sabbesu sattesu jinam ṭhapetvā na iva atthi paññāya samaḥ api yena
translated: Except for the Victor, there is no one equal to him in wisdom among all beings.

original: So dhammasenāpati sāvakopi gato mahārāja aniccataṃ’ca;
analyzed: saḥ dhamma senāpati sāvakaḥ api gataḥ mahā rāja anicca taṃ ca
translated: Even the General of the Dhamma, the disciple, went to the state of impermanence, O great king.

original: Sayambhūñāṇassa balena santiṃ gatā mahārāja sayambhūnopi,
analyzed: sayambhu ñāṇassa balena santim gatāḥ mahā rāja
translated: Even the Self-Existent One himself, by the power of the knowledge of the Self-Existent One, attained peace, O great king.

original: Sabbepi te ñāṇabalūpa pannā aniccataṃ neva atikkamiṃsu;
analyzed: sabbe api te ñāṇa bala upa pannāḥ anicca tam na iva atikkamiṃsu
translated: All of them, endowed with the power of knowledge, did not escape impermanence.

original: Tilokanātho purisuttamo so aniccabhāvaṃ samatikkamitvā,
analyzed: tilokanātho purisuttamo saḥ anicca bhāvam samatikkamitvā
translated: Even the Lord of the Three Worlds, the Supreme Man, having transcended the state of impermanence,

original: Nāsakkhi gantuṃ sugatopi rāja aññesu sattesu kathāva natthi;
analyzed: nā asakkhi gantum sugataḥ api rāja aññesu sattesu kathā va natthi
translated: Was unable to go beyond death, O king. It is not even a question of other beings.

original: Tasmā mahārāja bhavesu sattā sabbepi nāsuṃ maraṇā vimuttā,
analyzed: tasmai mahā rāja bhavesu sattā sabbe api na asum maraṇāḥ vimuttā
translated: Therefore, O great king, no beings in existence are free from death,

original: Sabbampi saṅkhāragataṃ aniccaṃ dūkkhaṃ anattāti vicintayassu;
analyzed: sabbam pi saṅkhāra gatam aniccam dūkkham anattā ati vicintayassu
translated: “Think over the whole of existence as impermanent, as painful, as not self.

original: “Dutiye attabhāvepi dhammacchaṇdo mahā hi te,
analyzed: dutiye atta bhāve pi dhammacchaṇdaḥ mahā hi te
translated: “In your second existence, too, you were a great devotee of the Dhamma.

original: Upaṭṭhite devaloke hitvā dibbasukhaṃ tuvaṃ;
analyzed: upaṭṭhite deva loke hitvā dibba sukham tuvam
translated: When you had passed away from the world of the gods and come down here,

original: Idhāgamma bahuṃ puññaṃ akāsi ca anekadhā,
analyzed: idha āgamma bahum puññam akāsi ca anekadhā
translated: you performed much merit in many ways.

original: Karaṇampeka rajjassa sāsanajjotanāya te;
analyzed: rajjassa te
translated: You had the palace built for the purpose of illuminating the Dispensation.

original: Mahā rāja kataṃ puññaṃ yāvajja divasā tayā,
analyzed: mahā rāja katam puññam yāvat ja divasā tayā
translated: Great king, the merit you have performed up to this day,

original: Sabbaṃ anussaretheva sukhaṃ sajju bhavissati;
analyzed: sabbam anussaretha iva sukham sajju bhavissati
translated: all that will follow you, and you will be happy for a long time.”

original: Taṃ sutvā tuṭṭhamānaso rājā bhante tumhe maccuyuddhepi apassayāti vatvā laddhassāso puññapotthakaṃ vācetuṃ āṇāpesi lekhako puññapotthakaṃ evaṃ vācesi.
analyzed: tam sutvā tuṭṭha mānasaḥ rājā bhante tumhe maccu yuddhe pi apassayā ti vatvā laddhassāsaḥ puñña potthakam vācetum āṇāpesi lekhako puñña potthakam evam vācesi
translated: When he had heard this, the king was delighted. “Venerable Sir, I have not seen you even in the war against death,” he said. Then he ordered the merit book to be read out. The scribe read out the merit book as follows:

original: “Ekūnasatavihārā mahārājena kāritā,
analyzed: ekūna sata vihārā mahā rājena kāritā
translated: “One hundred and nine monasteries were built by the Great King.

original: Ekūnasatakoṭīhi vihāro maricaṭṭi ca;
analyzed: ekūna sata koṭīhi vihāraḥ ca
translated: One hundred and nine koṭis were spent on the monastery and the Maricavattika.

original: Uttamo lohapāsādo tiṃsakoṭīhi kārito,🔽Mahāthūpe anagghāni kāritā catuvīsati;
analyzed: uttamaḥ loha pāsādaḥ tiṃsa koṭīhi kāritaḥ  mahāthūpe anagghāni kāritā catuvīsati
translated: The most excellent Lohapāsāda was built at a cost of thirty koṭis.🔽Twenty-four priceless objects were made for the Great Shrine.

original: Mahāthūpamhi sesāni karitāni subuddhinā,
analyzed: mahāthūpamhi sesāni karitāni subuddhinā
translated: The rest were made for the Great Shrine by the wise one.

original: Koṭisahassaṃ agghanti mahārāja tayā puna;
analyzed: koṭi sahassam mahā rāja tayā puna
translated: The value of these, O great king, is a thousand koṭis.

original: Koḷamba nāma maleya akkhakkhāyika chātake,
analyzed: koḷamba nāma maleya akkhakkhāyika chātake
translated: The earrings called Koḷambas, which were of great value,

original: Kuṇḍalāni mahagghāni duve datvāna gaṇhiya;
analyzed: kuṇḍalāni mahagghāni duve datvāna
translated: having given them away, he took the alms-bowl.

original: Khīṇāsavānaṃ pañcannaṃ mahātherānamuttamo,🔽Dinno pasannacittena kaṅgu ambila piṇḍako;🔽Cūḷaṅgaṇiya yuddhamhi parajjhitvā palāyatā,
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam  dinnaḥ pasanna cittena  yuddhamhi parajjhitvā palāyatā
translated: The most excellent of the five great Theras who were free from the corruptions,🔽gave with a faithful heart the Kaṅgu-mango.🔽Having been defeated in the battle of Cūḷaṅgaṇiya, and having fled,

original: Kālaṃ ghosāpayitvāna āgatassa vihāyasā;
analyzed: kālam ghosāpayitvānaḥ āgatassa vihāyasā
translated: having caused the time to be proclaimed, he came through the air.

original: Khīṇāsavassa yatino attānamanapekkhiya,
analyzed: khīṇa āsavassa yatinaḥ attānam an apekkhiya
translated: The ascetic who was free from the corruptions, not regarding his own person,

original: Dinnaṃ saraka bhattanti puññapotthaṃ avācayi;
analyzed: dinnam saraka bhattanti puñña pottham avācayi
translated: gave the Saraka rice. Thus he spoke about the heap of merit.

original: 25. Taṃ sutvā rājā tussitvā ṭhapehi ṭhapehi bhaṇeti vatvā evamāha. Maricavaṭṭi vihāramahasattāhe🔽thūpāramhasattāhe ca cātuddisa ubhato saṅghassa mahārahaṃ mahādānaṃ pavattesiṃ. Catuvīsati
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tussitvā ṭhapehi ṭhapehi bhaṇa iti vatvā evam āha maricavaṭṭi vihāra maha sattāhe  thūpa āramha sattāhe ca cātuddise ubhatas saṅghassa mahā raham mahā dānam catuvīsati
translated: Having heard that, the king was pleased, and saying: “Stop, stop,” he spoke thus: “I gave a great and valuable present to the Congregation of Bhikkhus of the four quarters,🔽at the time of the festival of the Thūpa, and at the time of the festival of the Mahāsatta.

original: mahāvisākhapūjā kāresiṃ tambapaṇṇidīpe mahābhikkhusaṅghassa tikkhattuṃ cīvaramadāsiṃ
analyzed: mahāvisākha pūjā kāresim tambapaṇṇi dīpe mahā bhikkhu saṅghassa tikkhattum cīvaram adāsim
translated: I celebrated the great festival of Visākhā twenty-four times. I gave three times robes to the great Congregation of Bhikkhus in Tambapaṇṇi.

original: satta satta dīnāni laṅkā rajjaṃ sāsanassa pañcakkhattuṃ adāsiṃ sappi sannitta suparisuddha
analyzed: satta satta dīnāni laṅkā rajjam sāsanassa pañcakkhattum adāsim
translated: For seven times seven years I gave the sovereignty of Laṅkā to the Faith. I had twelve oil-mills erected,

original: vaṭṭiyā dvādasaṭhānesu, sattaṃ dīpasahassaṃ jālesiṃ aṭṭhārassu ṭhānesu gilānānaṃ🔽vejjehi bhesajjañca bhattañca niccaṃ dāpesi. Catucattālīsa ṭhānesu telullopakañca
analyzed: vaṭṭiyāḥ dvādasa ṭhānesu sattam dīpa sahassam aṭṭhārassu ṭhānesu gilānānam  vejjehi bhesajjañca bhattañca niccam dāpesi ṭhānesu
translated: and caused seven thousand lamps to burn in the island. In eighty-four places I caused medicine and food to be distributed to the sick

original: adāsiṃ. Tattakesuyeva ṭhānesu ghatapakkajālapūve bhattena saddhiṃ niccaṃ dāpesiṃ.🔽Māse māse aṭṭhasu uposathadivasesu laṅkādīpe sabbavihāresu dīpatelaṃ dāpesiṃ. Āmisa🔽dānato dhammadānaṃ mahantanti sutvā heṭṭhaṃ lohapāsāde dhammāsane nisīditvā maṅgala🔽suttaṃ osāretuṃ ārabhitvāpi saṅgha gāravena osāretuṃ nāsakkhiṃ. Tato paṭṭhāya dhammadesake
analyzed: adāsim tattakesu yeva ṭhānesu ghata pakka jāla pūve bhattena saddhim niccam dāpesim  māse māse aṭṭhasu uposatha divasesu laṅkā dīpe sabba vihāresu dīpa telam āmisa  dānataḥ dhamma dānam mahantanti sutvā heṭṭham loha pāsāde dhamma āsane nisīditvā  suttam osāretum ārabhitvā api saṅgha gāravena osāretum na asakkhim tatas paṭṭhāya dhammadesake
translated: and the poor. In forty-four places I caused oil-cakes to be distributed. In the same places I caused rice-gruel and sweet cakes to be distributed to the poor.

original: sakkaritvā sabbavihāresu dhammakathaṃ kathāpesiṃ ekekassa dhammakathikassa nāḷa nāḷippamāṇāni
analyzed: sakkaritvā sabba vihāresu dhamma katham kathāpesim ekekassa dhamma kathikassa nāḷa nāḷippamāṇāni
translated: Every month on the eight Uposatha days I caused oil-lamps to be lighted in all the monasteries of the island. Having heard that the gift of the Faith is more excellent than the gift of material things, I ascended the pulpit of the lower Lohapāsāda, and began to recite the Mangala Sutta. But out of respect for the Congregation of Monks I was unable to finish it. From that time forth I honoured the preachers of the Faith, and caused the Dhamma to be preached in all the monasteries. To each preacher of the Faith I gave a nāḷi of oil-cakes,🔽and a nāḷi of rice.

original: sappiphāṇita sakkharāni caturaṅgula muṭṭhippamāṇaṃ yaṭṭhimadhukaṃ sāṭakadvayañca
analyzed: sappiphāṇita sakkharāni yaṭṭhimadhukam sāṭaka dvayam ca
translated: and four finger-breadths of honey on a stick, and two cloths.

original: māsassa aṭṭhasu uposatha disesu dāpesiṃ. Etaṃ sabbampi issariye ṭhatvā dinnattā mama
analyzed: māsassa aṭṭhasu uposatha disesu dāpesiṃ etam sabbam pi issariye ṭhatvā dinnattā mama
translated: On the eight Uposatha days of the month I gave these things. But all this, because it was given by me while I was in a position of authority,

original: cittaṃ sa ārādheti. Jīvitaṃ pana anapekkhitvā duggatena mayā dinnadānadvayameva ārādhetīti.
analyzed: cittam saḥ ārādhā iti jīvitam pana an apekkhitvā duggatena mayā dinna dāna dvayam eva ārādhā iti iti
translated: does not satisfy my mind. But the two gifts given by me when I was in a wretched state, without regard for my own life, these alone satisfy my mind.”

original: Taṃ sutvā abhayatthero mahārāja pasādanīyaṭṭhāneyeva pasādaṃ akāsi taṃ pana piṇḍapātadvayaṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā abhaya ttheraḥ mahā rāja pasādanīya ṭṭhāneya iva pasādam tam pana piṇḍapāta dvayam
translated: When he heard this, the Elder Abhaya said, “Great king, you have shown faith in the place where faith should be shown. But as for these two gifts of alms,

original: parissa pīḷaṃ akatvā laddha dhammika paccayattā attānaṃ anavaloketvā asajjamānena
analyzed: parissa pīḷam a katvā laddha dhammika paccaya ttā attānam an avaloketvā a sajjamānena
translated: they were given without regard for the giver’s own needs, and they were given without hesitation.

original: dinnattā paṭiggāhakānaṃ yāvadatthaṃ katvā dinnattā pītipāmojjaṃjanayitvā balava saddhāya
analyzed: dinnattā paṭiggāhakānam yāvadattham katvā dinnattā saddhāya
translated: They were given with strong faith, and they were given to satisfy the recipients to the full.

original: dinnattā deyyadhammassa niravasesaṃ paribhogaṃ gatattāti imehi pañcahi kāraṇehi mahantatti
analyzed: dinna ttā deyya dhammassa niravasesam paribhogam gata ttā ati imehi pañcahi kāraṇehi mahanta tti
translated: For these five reasons they are of great fruit and of great benefit.

original: vatvā mahārāja kaṅgu ambili piṇḍagāhakattheresu maliyamahādevatthero samantakūṭe
analyzed: vatvā mahā rāja kaṅgu ambili piṇḍagāhaka ttheresu maliya mahādeva ttheraḥ samantakūṭe
translated: “Great king, among the elders Kaṅkhārevata, Ambakāsutta, Piṇḍolabhāradvāja, Maliyadeva, and Samantakūṭa,

original: pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ datvā paribhuñji pathavi cālanaka dhammaguttatthero kalyāṇīya🔽vihāre pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ datvā paribhuñji.
analyzed: pañcannam bhikkhu satānam da tvā paribhuñji  vihāre pañcannam bhikkhu satānam da tvā paribhuñji
translated: and the Elder Dhammagutta, who caused the earth to tremble, gave it to five hundred bhikkhus and used it himself at the Kalyāṇī Vihāra.

original: Talaṅgaravāsī dhammaguttattheropi piyaṅgudīpe dvādasannaṃ bhikkhusahassānaṃ datvā
analyzed: talaṅgara vāsī dhammagutta theraḥ api piyaṅgu dīpe dvādasannam bhikkhu sahassānam da tvā
translated: and the Elder Dhammagutta, who lived at Talaṅgara, gave it to twelve thousand bhikkhus and used it himself in the Island of Piyaṅgu.

original: paribhuñji. Maṅgaṇavāsī cuḷatissatthero kelāsakūṭe vihāre saṭṭhisahassānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: paribhuñji maṅgaṇa vāsī cuḷatissa theraḥ kelāsakūṭe vihāre saṭṭhi sahassānam bhikkhūnam
translated: and the Elder Culla-Tissa, who lived at Maṅgala, gave it to sixty thousand bhikkhus and used it himself at the Vihāra on Kelāsa Peak.

original: datvā paribhuñji mahābhaggattheropi ukkānagara vihāre sattasatānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ datvā
analyzed: da tvā paribhuñji mahābhagga ttheraḥ api ukkā nagara vihāre satta satānam bhikkhūnam da tvā
translated: and the Elder Mahā-Bhaggā gave it to seven hundred bhikkhus and used it himself at the Vihāra in the city of Ukkā.

original: paribhuñji saraka bhattagāhakatthero pana piyaṅgudīpe dvādasannaṃ bhikkhusahassānaṃ
analyzed: paribhuñji bhatta gāhaka thero pana piyaṅgu dīpe dvādasannam bhikkhu sahassānam
translated: and the Elder Saraka-Bhattagāhaka gave it to twelve thousand bhikkhus and used it himself in the Island of Piyaṅgu.

original: datvā paribhogamakāsīti vatvā rañño cittaṃ hāsesi.
analyzed: da tvā paribhogam akāsi iti vatvā rañño cittam hāsesi
translated: and he amused the king’s mind by saying this.

original: Rājā cittaṃ pasādetvā evamāha-ahambhante catuvīsati vassāni rajjaṃ kārento bhikkhusaṅghassa
analyzed: rājā cittam pasādetvā evam āha aham bhante catuvīsati vassāni rajjam kārentaḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: The king, having been pleased, said this: “Venerable sirs, I, having reigned for twenty-four years, gave to the Community of Bhikkhus

original: pahūpakāro ahosiṃ. Kāyopi me saṅghassa upakārako hotu saṅghadāsassa me sarīraṃ mahācetiyassa
analyzed: pahu upakāraḥ ahosim kāyaḥ api me saṅghassa upakārakaḥ hotu saṅgha dāsassa me sarīram mahā cetiyassa
translated: and I have been a great benefactor to the Order. Let my body also be a benefactor to the Order. Let my corpse be burnt in the cremation-ground of the Order, in the place where the Order sees to it that the Great Shrine is worshipped.’

original: dassanaṭṭhāne saṅghassa kammamālake jhāpethāti. Tato kaniṭṭhaṃ āmantetvā’tāta! Tissa!🔽Mahāthūpe aniṭṭhitaṃ kammaṃ sādhukaṃ niṭṭhāpesi. Sāyaṃ pāto ca mahāthūpe pupphapūjaṃ
analyzed: dassana ṭṭhāne saṅghassa kamma mālake jhāpetha ati tatas kaniṭṭham āmantetvā atāta tissa  mahā thūpe aniṭṭhitam kammam sādhukam niṭṭhāpesi sāyam pāto ca mahā thūpe puppha pūjam
translated: Then he addressed his youngest son, saying: ‘Dear Tissa!

original: kāretvā tikkhattuṃ upahāraṃ kārehi. Mayā ṭhapitaṃ dānavaṭṭaṃ sabbaṃ aparihāpetvā
analyzed: kāretvā tikkhattum upahāram kārehi mayā ṭhapitam dānavaṭṭam sabbam a parihāpetvā
translated: and he had the unfinished work on the Great Shrine well completed. From this day forth let the Great Shrine be worshipped with flowers and let offerings be made to it three times a day. Let not the distribution of alms which I have instituted be neglected.

original: saṅghassa kattabbakiccesu sadā appamatto hohī’ti anusāyitvā tuṇhi ahosi.
analyzed: saṅghassa kattabba kiccesu sadā appamattaḥ hohi iti tuṇhi ahosi
translated: Be always careful in the duties which you owe to the Order.’ After giving this advice he became silent.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe bhikkhu gaṇasajjhāyaṃ ārabhiṃsu devatā pana chadeva lokato cha rathe🔽gahetvā ādāya paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapetvā mahārāja amhākaṃ devaloko ramaṇīyo, amhākaṃ devaloko
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe bhikkhu gaṇa sajjhāyam ārabhiṃsu devatā pana chadeva lokataḥ cha rathe  gahetvā ādāya paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapetvā mahā rāja amhākam deva lokaḥ ramaṇīyaḥ amhākam deva lokaḥ
translated: At that moment the multitude of monks began to discuss the matter, but the deities, having taken six chariots from the six worlds,🔽placed them in a row and said: ‘Great King, our heavenly world is delightful, our heavenly world is delightful.’ They asked the king to allow them to return to their own heavenly worlds. The king accepted their request,

original: ramaṇīyoti vatvā attano attano devalokaṃ āgamanatthāya yāciṃsu rājā tesaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: ramaṇīyaḥ iti vatvā attano attano deva lokaṃ āgamana tthāya yāciṃsu rājā tesam vacanaṃ
translated: and he had the chariots placed in the place where the Great Shrine was worshipped.

original: sutvā yāvāhaṃ dhammaṃ suṇāmi- tāva adhivāsethāti te hatthasaññāya nivāresi saṅgho
analyzed: sutvā yāva aham dhammam suṇāmi tāva adhivāsetha ati te hattha saññāya nivāresi saṅghaḥ
translated: and he said, “Let the Sangha wait until I have heard the Dhamma.” He stopped them by a mere gesture of his hand.

original: gaṇasajjhāyaṃ nivāresīti maññitvā sajjhāyaṃ ṭhapāpesi.
analyzed: gaṇa sajjhāyam nivāresi iti maññitvā sajjhāyam ṭhapāpesi
translated: The Sangha thought, “He stops us from reciting the scriptures,” and so they stopped reciting the scriptures.🔽The king asked, “Why, venerable sirs, have you stopped reciting the scriptures?”

original: Rājā kasmā bhante gaṇasajjhāyaṃ ṭhapethāti āha. Mahārāja tayā hatthasaññāya nivāritattāti.🔽Bhante tumhākaṃ saññaṃ nādāsiṃ. Devatā chadevalokato cha rathe ānetvā attano attano
analyzed: rājā kasmai bhante gaṇa sajjhāyam ṭhapetha ati āha mahā rāja tayā hattha saññāya nivārita ttā ati  bhante tumhākam saññam devatā cha deva lokataḥ cha rathe ānetvā attano attano
translated: “Great king, you stopped us by a mere gesture of your hand.”🔽“Venerable sirs, I did not stop you. The deities have brought six chariots from the six divine worlds. They want to go back to their own divine worlds.

original: devalokaṃ gantuṃ yācanti tasmā tesaṃ yāvāhaṃ dhammaṃ suṇāmi tāva āgamethāti saññaṃ🔽adāsinti taṃ sutvā keci ayaṃ rājā maraṇabhayabhito vippalapati, maraṇato abhāyanaka
analyzed: deva lokam gantum yācanti tasmā tesam yāva aham dhammam suṇāmi tāva āgametha ati saññam  tam sutvā keci ayam rājā maraṇa bhaya bhitas vippalapati maraṇataḥ
translated: I told them to wait until I had heard the Dhamma.

original: satto nāma natthīti maññiṃsu.
analyzed: sattaḥ nāma na atthi iti maññiṃsu
translated: ” When they heard this, some thought, “This king is babbling out of fear of death. There is no being who is not afraid of death.”

original: Tato abhayatthero āha kathaṃ mahārāja saddahituṃ sakkā cha devalokato cha rathā ānītāti
analyzed: tatas abhaya theraḥ āha katham mahā rāja saddahitum sakkā cha deva lokataḥ cha rathāḥ ānītāḥ ati
translated: Then the elder Abhaya said, “How can you believe this, great king, that six chariots have been brought from the six divine worlds?”

original: taṃ sutvā rājā ākāse pupphadāmāni khipāpesi. Tāni gantvā visuṃ rathadhure olambiṃsu
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā ākāse puppha dāmāni khipāpesi tāni gantvā visum ratha dhure olambiṃsu
translated: When the king heard this, he had garlands of flowers thrown into the air. They went and hung on the yokes of the chariots one by one.

original: mahājano ākāse olambantāni pupphadāmāni disvā nikkaṅkho ahosi.
analyzed: mahā janaḥ ākāse olambantāni puppha dāmāni disvā nikkaṅkhaḥ ahosi
translated: The multitude, seeing the garlands of flowers hanging in the air, were convinced.

original: Tato rājā theraṃ pucchi-katamo pana bhante devaloko ramaṇīyoti. Tusitabhavanaṃ pana
analyzed: tatas rājā theram pucchikatamaḥ pana bhante deva lokaḥ tusita bhavanam pana
translated: Then the king asked the Thera, “But, venerable sir, which is the most delightful of the celestial worlds?” “The Tusita palace,

original: mahārāja ramaṇīyaṃ, buddhabhāvāya samayaṃ olokento metteyyo bodhisattopi tasmiṃyeva vasatīti āha.
analyzed: mahā rāja ramaṇīyam buddha bhāvāya samayam olokentaḥ metteyyaḥ bodhisattaḥ api tasmin yeva vasati iti āha
translated: great king, is delightful. The Bodhisatta Metteyya, who is looking for the time to attain Buddhahood, dwells there.”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā tasmiṃ ālayaṃ katvā mahāthūpaṃ olokento nipannova cavitvā suttappabuddho
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tasmin ālayam katvā mahā thūpam olokentaḥ nipannaḥ iva cavitvā sutta ppabuddhaḥ
translated: Having heard this, the king fixed his thoughts on that world, and as he looked at the Great Shrine he died, and was reborn in the Tusita palace,

original: viya tusita bhavanato āhaṭa. Rathe nibbattitvā attano katapuññassa thalaṃ mahājanassa🔽pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ ratheyeva ṭhatvā dibbābharaṇa vibhūsito mahājanassa passantasseva tikkhattuṃ
analyzed: viya tusita bhavanataḥ āhaṭa rathe nibbattitvā attano kata puññassa thalam mahājanassa  pākaṭam kātum ṭhatvā dibba ābharaṇa vibhūsitaḥ mahā janassa passantassa iva tikkhattum
translated: as if he had awakened from sleep. He was seated in a chariot, and in order to make manifest to the multitude the fruit of his own merit,

original: mahāthūpaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā bhikkhusaṅghañca vaṇditvā tusitabhavanaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: mahā thūpam padakkhiṇam katvā bhikkhu saṅghañca vaṇditvā tusita bhavanam agamāsi
translated: he circumambulated the Great Shrine three times, standing in the chariot, and, adorned with celestial ornaments, he bowed to the Congregation of Bhikkhus, while the multitude looked on, and then he went to the Tusita palace.

original: Evaṃ asāre nicaye dhanānaṃ aniccasaṅghaṃ sattaṃ sapaññā,
analyzed: evam asāre nicaye dhanānam anicca saṅgham sattam sa paññā
translated: Thus, having seen the impermanence of the seven treasures, the insubstantiality of the mass of wealth, the wise one,

original: Katvana cāgaṃ ratanattayamahi ādāya sāraṃ sugatiṃ vajanti;🔽Rañño nāṭakatthiyo matabhāvaṃ ñatvā yattha ṭhitā makuḷaṃ mocayiṃsu tatthaṃ ṭhāne
analyzed: ādāya sāram su gatim vajanti  raññaḥ nāṭakatthiyaḥ mata bhāvam ñatvā yattha ṭhitāḥ makuḷam mocayiṃsu tattham ṭhāne
translated: Having made a gift, and taken the essence of the Three Jewels, they went to a happy state of existence.🔽The king’s dancing-girls, having understood that he was dead, where they had stood and let fall their lotuses,

original: katasālā makuḷamuttasālānāmajātā. Rañño sarīrasmiṃ citakaṃ āropite yattha mahājano
analyzed: katasālāḥ makuḷa muttasālā nāma jātāḥ rañño sarīrasmiṃ citakam āropite yattha mahājano
translated: there a hall was built, and it was called the Hall of the Lotuses. When the king’s body was placed on the funeral pyre, where the multitude

original: hatthe paggahetvā viraci. Tattha katasālā viracitthasālā nāma jātā. Rañño sarīraṃ
analyzed: hatthe paggahetvā viraci tattha kata sālā viracitthasālā nāma jātā rañño sarīram
translated: took hold of the hands and wailed, there a hall was built, and it was called the Hall of the Wails. When the king’s body

original: yattha jhāpesuṃ - so sīmāmālako rājamālako nāma jāto. Atha rañño kaniṭṭhabhātā saddhātissamahārājā
analyzed: yattha jhāpesum saḥ sīmāmālakaḥ rājamālakaḥ nāma jātaḥ atha raññaḥ kaniṭṭha bhātā saddhātissa mahā rājā
translated: was burnt, where they extinguished the fire, that place was called the Royal Extinguisher. Then the king’s younger brother, the faithful King Tissa,

original: nāma hutvā cetiye aniṭṭhataṃ jattakammaṃ sudhākammañca niṭṭhāpetvā thūpamakāsīti
analyzed: nāma hutvā cetiye jatta kammam sudhā kammam ca niṭṭhāpetvā thūpam akāsi iti
translated: having completed the work of building the Cetiya and the work of plastering it, built the Thūpa.

original: Iti sādhujana manopasādanatthāya kate thūpavaṃse mahācetiye katā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iti sādhu jana mana upasādana tthāya kate thūpavaṃse mahā cetiye katā niṭṭhitā
translated: Thus in the Thūpa Vamsa, composed for gladdening the minds of good people, the building of the Great Cetiya is finished.

original: 26. Etarahi duṭṭhagāmaṇi abhaya mahārājassa pitā kākavaṇṇatissa rājā metteyyassa
analyzed: etarahi duṭṭhagāmaṇi abhaya mahā rājassa pitā kākavaṇṇatissa rājā metteyyassa
translated: Now the wicked Gaṇi Abhaya, the father of King Mahinda, King Kākavaṇṇa Tissa,

original: bhagavato pitā bhavissati. Vihāramahādevī mātā bhavissati. Duṭṭhagāmiṇi abhayo aggasāvako
analyzed: bhagavato pitā bhavissati vihāramahādevī mātā bhavissati duṭṭhagāmiṇi abhayaḥ aggasāvako
translated: will be the father of the Lord, the Great Queen of the Monastery will be the mother, the Wicked One will be the chief male lay disciple,

original: bhavissati. Kaniṭṭho dutiya sāvako bhavisasati. Rañño pitucchā anuḷādevī aggamahesī
analyzed: bhavissati kaniṭṭhaḥ dutiya sāvakaḥ bhavisasati raññaḥ pitucchā anuḷādevī aggamahesī
translated: the younger brother will be the second chief male lay disciple, the King’s father’s sister will be the chief female lay disciple,

original: bhavissati. Rañño putto sāli rājakumāro putto bhavissati. Bhaṇḍāgārika saṅghāmacco
analyzed: bhavissati rañño putto sāli rāja kumāro putto bhavissati saṅgha amaccaḥ
translated: the King’s son, Prince Sāli, will be the son, the treasurer Saṅgha, the chief minister,

original: aggupaṭṭhāko bhavissati tassāmaccassa dhītā aggupaṭṭhāyikā bhavissatīti evaṃ sabbepi
analyzed: aggupaṭṭhākaḥ bhavissati tassa amaccassa dhītā aggupaṭṭhāyikā bhavissati iti evam sabbe pi
translated: will be the chief supporter, and the treasurer’s daughter will be the chief female supporter.” Thus all of them,

original: katādhikārā hetu sampannā tassa bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā dukkhassantaṃ karitvā anupādisesāya
analyzed: kata adhikārā hetu sampannā tassa bhagavataḥ dhammam sutvā dukkhassantam karitvā an upādisesāya
translated: having performed their duties, having attained the cause, having heard the Lord’s Teaching, having made an end of suffering, will attain complete extinction

original: nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyissantīti.
analyzed: nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbāyissanti iti
translated: in the element of extinction without trace left.

original: Ettāvatā ca
analyzed: ettāvatā ca
translated: And at this point

original: Mahiṇdasena nāmamhi vasanto pariveṇake,
analyzed: mahiṇdasena nāmamhi vasantaḥ pariveṇake
translated: I, who am called Mahiṇḍa, living in a cloister,

original: Pattacīvarapādo? Yo piṭakattaya pārago;
analyzed: patta cīvara pādaḥ yaḥ piṭaka ttaya pārago
translated: having a bowl, robe, and foot-stool, who am skilled in the three Baskets,

original: Saddhāsilaguṇupeto sabbasattahite rato,
analyzed: saddhā sila guṇa upetaḥ sabba satta hite rataḥ
translated: endowed with faith and virtue, delighting in the welfare of all beings,

original: Tena sādhu samajjhiṭṭho yamahaṃ kātumārabhiṃ;
analyzed: tena sādhu samajjhiṭṭhaḥ yam aham kātum ārabhim
translated: having well considered this, I will now begin to write;

original: Sodāni niṭṭhaṃ sampatto thūpavaṃso anākulo,
analyzed: niṭṭham sampattaḥ thūpa vaṃsaḥ an ākulaḥ
translated: having now reached the end, the Chronicle of the Thūpa is complete.

original: Paripuṇṇo saṅkhathā sādhu paṇḍitehi pasaṃsito;
analyzed: paripuṇṇaḥ saṅkhathā sādhu paṇḍitehi pasaṃsitaḥ
translated: Is complete, well-praised by the wise;

original: Yaṃ pattaṃ kusalaṃ kammaṃ karontena imaṃ mayaṃ,
analyzed: yam pattam kusalam kammam karontena imam mayam
translated: That good deed which has been done by us,

original: Tena etena puññena sattā gacchantu nibbutiṃ;
analyzed: tena etena puññena sattāḥ gacchantu nibbutim
translated: By that merit may beings go to Nibbāna;

original: Anantarāyena yathā ca siddhiṃ
analyzed: anantarāyena yathā ca siddhim
translated: And may they attain success without hindrance

original: Mūpāgato thūpavarassa vaṃso,
analyzed: thūpa varassa vaṃso
translated: The lineage of the most excellent Thūpa has been brought to an end,

original: Tatheva saddhammasitā janānaṃ
analyzed: tathā iva saddhamma sitā janānam
translated: And in the same way may the minds of people who are purified by the True Dhamma

original: Mano rathā sīghamupentu siddhiṃ;🔽Parisambhidāmaggassa yena līlattha dīpani
analyzed: manaḥ rathā sīgham upentu siddhim  parisambhidā maggassa yena dīpani
translated: Swiftly attain success;🔽By whom the commentary was well composed, desiring the rising of the True Dhamma,

original: Ṭīkā viracitā sādhu saddhammodaya kāminā;
analyzed: ṭīkā viracitā sādhu saddhamma udaya kāminā
translated: Illuminating the path of the analytical knowledges, for the sake of play;

original: Tathā pakaraṇe saccasaṅkhepe atthadīpanā,
analyzed: tathā pakaraṇe sacca saṅkhepe attha dīpanā
translated: In the same way, the explanation of the meaning in the treatise called the “Summary of the Truths,”

original: Dhīmatā sukatā yena suṭṭhu sīhaḷa bhāsato
analyzed: dhīmatā su katā yena suṭṭhu
translated: Was well done by the wise one in the Sinhalese language;

original: Visuddhimagga saṅkhepe yena atthappakāsanā,
analyzed: visuddhi magga saṅkhepe yena attha ppakāsanā
translated: In the “Summary of the Path of Purification,” by whom the explanation of the meaning

original: Yogī namupakārāya katā sīhaḷabhāsato;
analyzed: yogī
translated: Was done in the Sinhalese language for the benefit of meditators;

original: Parakkama nariṇdassa sabbabhūpāna ketuno,
analyzed: parakkama nariṇdassa sabba bhūpāna ketunaḥ
translated: Of Parakkama, the lord of men, the banner of all kings,

original: Dhammāgāre niyutto yo piṭakattaya pārago;
analyzed: dhamma āgāre niyuttaḥ yaḥ piṭaka ttaya pārago
translated: Who was devoted to the Dhamma, and had mastered the three Piṭakas;

original: Sāsanaṃ suṭṭhitaṃ yassa antevāsika bhikkhusu,
analyzed: sāsanam suṭṭhitam yassa antevāsika bhikkhusu
translated: Whose Dispensation was well-established among the bhikkhus who were his pupils,

original: Tena vācissaratthera pādena likhito ayanti;
analyzed: tena pādena likhitaḥ
translated: By whom this was written with the foot of the Elder Vācissara;

original: Thūpavaṃso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: thūpa vaṃsaḥ niṭṭhito
translated: The History of the Relic Shrine is finished.
